newsitem.title: SPAIN: TELEFONICA - UNISOURCE TALKS TO END SOON.
newsitem.headline: TELEFONICA - UNISOURCE TALKS TO END SOON.

text.p: Telefonica de Espana SA's chairman said negotiations with former partner Unisource would end soon now that the telecommunication firm had allied with British Telecommunications Plc and U.S.-based MCI Communications Corp .
In a interview published in El Pais on Monday, chairman Juan Villalonga said talks with Unisource are likely to end soon.

"We'll start negotiations and since we have a good relationship there will be a deal soon. We'll recover the data transmission firm we brought (valued around 65 billion pesetas) and we'll have to sell Unisource's shares," he said.
Telefonica also responded to critics of the deal, who said the company seemed to have surrendered to bigger competitors.
"This alliance is an opportunity and not a threat," Villalonga told the newspaper.
He stressed that the deal did not entail a merger.
Last Friday, Telefonica said it had formed a global telecommunications alliance with BT and MCI to create one of the world's top five telecoms operators.
That was considered Telefonica's first step out of its previous international alliance, the Unisource group.
On Saturday, El Pais, commenting on the shift in alliances, said: "It could be said Telefonica has changed from being the head of the mouse to being the tail of a lion".
And in this morning's interview, Villalonga said "We were not a mouse's head before and now we are not the lion's tail, because this is a alliance and not a merger."
Financial daily Cinco Dias said on Monday that this alliance made Telefonica English.
"For Telefonica the British alliance is to rule out a frightening competitor in the domestic market and to find a strong ally outside home," the daily wrote.
Villalonga said in the interview that pressure from competitors was forcing the deal.

"The unstoppable globalisation process in the telecommunications forced us to change our strategic view. We needed a very strong ally, with knowledge and financial strength to help us to get stronger in the Spanish speaking market," Villalonga added.
Unisource has been jointly owned by four European telephone companies: Telefonica, Koninklijke PTT Nederland NV , Telia of Sweden and Swiss Telecom.
